First of all, let’s note that we should never expect unemployment, as currently measured, to go away completely. Economists agree that a certain percentage of workers will always be transitioning between jobs at a given time. In the US, it is generally agreed that this so-called “natural rate of unemployment” is around 5%. It is possible for the rate to go below this number temporarily, but it isn’t generally sustainable outside of a war mobilization situation. Now, unemployment above the natural rate is a problem. If it exists, then by definition there must be a detectable number of workers who want jobs but can’t find them. This means that at the currently existing wages, there are more workers that want jobs than open jobs available. How can we fix this? Many ways: Kill the unemployed. Not really on the table but it works; the Black Death caused a massive increase in wages for the survivors and there sure wasn’t an unemployment problem anymore.Wait. Eventually employers will notice that they can pay workers less, so wages will drop, which will do two things. First, it will cause some employers to want to hire. Second, some workers will stop looking for jobs, or maybe cut back on their hours, second jobs, etc. Eventually we hit the point where supply equals demand and we’re back to no structural unemployment. Also, over time, workers will retrain so that they are more desirable to employers, which will cause them to get hired.Do stuff that will cause wages to decrease. Remove regulations like minimum wage laws that drive up wages. Make it harder for unions to do the stuff they do.Do stuff that will get workers to accept lower wages. Cut unemployment and welfare benefits.Cause inflation, and make it hard for businesses to raise wages to match. For bonus points, make it possible for some sectors of the economy to raise wages, and impossible for others, based on politics. (Or even more fun reasons like racism).Do stuff that will get workers to leave the labor force entirely (stop looking for jobs). This is kind of an abuse of the fact that the unemployment rate doesn’t count people who aren’t looking for jobs.Do stuff that encourages hiring at the current wages. This is what most people actually want the government to do. Cut payroll taxes. Hand out subsidies to employers who hire the unemployed.Have the government create jobs. Increase spending on public projects. For a more extreme version, pay people to do useless stuff like digging holes and them filling them in again. Some New Deal programs in the 1930s US were not too far removed from that.Now, the stuff that tends to work reliably and without causing other problems (at least what economists view as problems) are the first 4. Note that these are all unpopular to varying degrees. It is a reasonable point of view that unemployment means that workers either lack skills that actually produce value for employers, or are asking for too much money for the skills they actually have. The more popular stuff either tends to make utter chaos out of the economy (inflation, regulations aimed at forcing businesses not to fire peope), or require increased levels of taxation, which eventually harms economic growth. So popular policies tend to have a flavor of solving short-term problems by creating long-term ones. If we want to help people who are unemployed, (which I think is a good idea, as do most people), it’s probably better to simply help out those who are poor for whatever reason, and let the labor market take care of itself. Mix in programs intended to help the low-skilled workers acquire more skills (and free/cheap college is a very inefficient way to do this) to taste.

Although there can be several different approaches to reducing unemployment, there really is only one real danger currently to people having jobs and it's not what most people would believe. The story of the unemployment rate in America right now is true that it is at all-time lows. It is also true that wages are up for most workers. However, these are not the full story and it is important to look at the big picture for most of middle America. Workers are employed, but they are many times working for less and working more hours to earn that larger paycheck. You might be asking yourself how people that are employed are earning less when wages are reported as being up. This does, after all, seem to contradict the national news of low unemployment and higher wages. The issue today in America is the costs of living. Wages are up, but so are expenses for healthcare, education, and housing. This is in addition to just the daily increasing living expenses most people experience. Think about the last time something as simple as your cable bill or garbage pickup increased in price. I know for me, these expenses go up a little each and every year. When it comes to the costs of education, housing, and healthcare, these expenses are most often outpacing inflation and those increased wages reported that so many people are earning. The gain in pay reported in the current economy is most often a net and sometimes even a negative gain. While people are earning more the costs are also more. An increase in wages is also the result of Americans working more. For hourly workers that receive overtime, they are indeed making more. They are just working more hours for it. It is also not uncommon for numerous workers to have a second job or what is commonly referred to as a side hustle to make some extra money. Again, not actually making more money, but working more for an increase in income. An increasing number of American companies and businesses are moving to a leaner working environment. What this means is they are many times reducing their headcount and having fewer employees do the work of more with an increase in responsibilities. This is nothing new and the trend is only likely to continue as businesses keep trying to compete globally and increase their bottom line along with shareholder profits. The real problem that is lingering when it comes to unemployment in America is not helping individuals or businesses with taxes, but outsourcing jobs in favor of cheaper labor and moving everything made in America overseas. This is the real employment killer. The issue today is there are a lot fewer manufacturing jobs in America than there were decades ago. America has moved to more of a service and entertainment industry. While the entertainment industry in America still brings in quite a lot of money, the service industry as a whole does not. This is particularly the case when you compare many service jobs to manufacturing positions that have been eliminated. Dollar for dollar most manufacturing jobs make more money compared to service positions. Sure, doctors and lawyers are a service business. However, there are a lot more Walmart and Target workers in America. Outsourcing jobs in favor of less expensive labor has also been an issue with employment. Take a real long look at the work visa programs that many larger companies use still. These were originally put in place to fill a shortage of highly educated American workers. If you really research the issue, you will find this has been anything but the truth in many instances. To this day many older workers in the technology industry are still being phased out and replaced by less expensive foreign employees. Although writing code and being in the software industry seem to be in high demand and it probably still is, if you are an older worker in this industry you need to be concerned. The real job killer in America today and for quite a while now have been Americans. The need for cheaper goods in combination with outsourcing and chasing increasingly larger shareholder profits is the problem. China is a big issue when it comes to jobs in America. The US has moved so many manufacturing jobs to China with the need for larger profits and to compete around the world. A race for the lowest price is a problem and it hasn’t only hurt American’s and their jobs. It also has hurt their wallets and life. Unlike quality goods made in America decades ago, today’s US consumer is built on low quality low priced goods. Yes, a lot of the prices are cheap. However, many times people are spending much more money, in the long run, having to constantly buy the same things repeatedly. Not knowing Americans are being trained to be poor. We are being trained by the large corporations who figured out how to maximize their profits. Think about everything in America that now predominantly comes from China and other overseas suppliers. When you buy something do you commonly see “American Made?” The answer is no. The reason is not much is made in America any longer. Although employment issues in America can be tied to the loss of manufacturing jobs and also outsourcing many of them, the real danger is looming for Americans. What is this real danger? It is national security.  Think about this for a minute. During World War II American manufacturing was big. We were able to build our own ships and other supplies for the war efforts. Now think about not having all of this manufacturing infrastructure in place and there is a conflict with the same country that makes everything we buy. They certainly aren’t going to sell things to a country they have an issue with. The real way to probably decrease unemployment in America is to try and start purchasing more things made in the USA. Don’t make weekly trips to Walmart. Invest in quality over quantity and a cheap price. Destruction of Jobs … In almost every case, government programs are the cause of joblessness. Minimum Wage. The minimum wage mandates that wages be set at a government-determined level. To explain why this is harmful, we can use an analogy from biology: there are certain animals that are weak compared to others. For example, the porcupine is defenseless except for its quills, the deer vulnerable except for its speed.In economics there are also people who are relatively weak. The disabled, the young, minorities, the untrained—all are weak economic actors. But like the weak animals in biology, they have a compensating advantage: the ability to work for lower wages. When the government takes this ability away from them by forcing up pay scales, it is as if the porcupine were shorn of its quills. The result is unemployment, which creates desperate loneliness, isolation, and dependency.Consider a young, uneducated, unskilled person, whose productivity is $2.50 an hour in the marketplace. What if the legislature passes a law requiring that he be paid $5 per hour? The employer hiring him would lose $2.50 an hour.Consider a man and a woman each with a productivity of $10 per hour, and suppose, because of discrimination or whatever, that the man is paid $ 10 per hour and the woman is paid $8 per hour. It is as if the woman had a little sign on her forehead saying, "Hire me and earn an extra $2 an hour."This makes her a desirable employee even for a sexist boss. But when an equal-pay law stipulates that she must be paid the same as the man, the employer can indulge his discriminatory tendencies and not hire her at all, at no cost to himself.Comparable Worth. What if government gets the bright idea that nurses and truck drivers ought to be paid the same wage because their occupations are of "intrinsically" equal value? It orders that nurses' wages be raised to the same level, which creates unemployment for women.Working Conditions. Laws which force employers to provide certain types of working conditions also create unemployment. For example, migrant fruit and vegetables pickers must have hot and cold running water and modern toilets in the temporary cabins provided for them. This is economically equivalent to wage laws because, from the point of view of the employer, working conditions are almost indistinguishable from money wages. And if the government forces him to pay more, he will have to hire fewer people.Unions. When the government forces businesses to hire only union workers, it discriminates against non-union workers, causing them to be at a severe disadvantage or permanently unemployed. Unions exist primarily to keep out competition. They are a state-protected cartel like any other.Employment Protection. Employment protection laws, which mandate that no one can be fired without due process, are supposed to protect employees. However, if the government tells the employer that he must keep the employee no matter what, he will tend not to hire him in the first place. This law, which appears to help workers, instead keeps them from employment. And so do employment taxes and payroll taxes, which increase costs to businesses and discourage them from hiring more workers.Payroll Taxes. Payroll taxes like Social Security impose heavy monetary and administrative costs on businesses, drastically increasing the marginal cost of hiring new employees.Unemployment Insurance. Government unemployment insurance and welfare cause unemployment by subsidizing idleness. When a certain behavior is subsidized—in this case not working—we get more of it.Licensing. Regulations and licensing also cause unemployment. Most people know that doctors and lawyers must have licenses. But few know that ferret breeders, falconers, and strawberry growers must also have them. In fact, government regulates over 1,000 occupations in all 50 states. A woman in Florida who ran a soup kitchen for the poor out of her home was recently shut down as an unlicensed restaurant, and many poor people now go hungry as a result.When the government passes a law saying certain jobs cannot be undertaken without a license, it erects a legal barrier to entry. Why should it be illegal for anyone to try their hand at hair-cutting? The market will supply all the information consumers need.When the government bestows legal status on a profession and passes a law against competitors, it creates unemployment. For example, who lobbies for the laws which prevent just anyone from giving a haircut? The hair-cutting industry—not to protect the consumer from bad haircuts, but to protect themselves against competition.Peddling. Laws against street peddlers prevent people from selling food and products to people who want them. In cities like New York and Washington, D.C., the most vociferous supporters of anti-peddling laws are established restaurants and department stores.Child Labor. There are many jobs that require little training—such as mowing lawns—which are perfect for young people who want to earn some money. In addition to the earnings, working also teaches young people what a job is, how to handle money, and how to save and maybe even invest. But in most places, the government discriminates against teenagers and prevents them from participating in the free enterprise system. Kids can't even have a street-corner lemonade stand.The Federal Reserve. By bringing about the business cycle, Federal Reserve money creation causes unemployment. Inflation not only raises prices, it also misallocates labor. During the boom phase of the trade cycle, businesses hire new workers, many of whom are pulled from other lines of work by the higher wages. The Fed subsidy to these capital industries lasts only until the bust. Workers are then laid off and displaced.The Free Market. The free market, of course, does not mean Utopia. We live in a world of differing intelligence and skills, of changing market preferences, and of imperfect information, which can lead to temporary, market-generated unemployment, which Mises called "catallactic." And some people choose unemployment by holding out for a higher paying job.But as a society, we can insure that everyone who wants to work has a chance to do so by repealing minimum wage law, comparable worth rules, working condition laws, compulsory union membership, employment protection, employment taxes, payroll taxes, government unemployment insurance, welfare, regulations, licensing, anti-peddling laws, child-labor laws, and government money creation. The path to jobs that matter is the free market.Source: How the Market Creates Jobs and How the Government Destroys Them (Full Edition) I hope this helps.

"Crisis"? Perhaps the best way to handle the "unemployment crisis" is stop listening to politicians. Unemployment is at one of its lowest points in the past 10 years, so clearly if there were a "crisis" then, congratulations, we have ended it. Woo hoo, break out the champagne. Now, if you are asking "how do we solve the employment skills problem" then we have a different discussion. 30+ years ago there was a lot of manufacturing being done in the US than there is today.  It used to be that a manufacturing job allowed a for a wage that could support a family. But then all of the manufacturing went offshore.  Now you can blame it on greedy manufacturers trying to make a quick buck, but if you want the real culprit, look in the mirror. American consumers now get more for their dollar than ever before. Technology has provided some innovation but much of that increase in value is because we as a people have pushed down the price of labor.  Basically you can't afford to pay people to manufacture things in this country much anymore.  The problem is not unemployment, the problem is a wage gap. Here are two ways to handle the problem:  Cost and education. The first is ugly.  If you want to "bring manufacturing back to the US" as some presidential hopefuls have bragged, get ready to pay more.  There are clearly documented cases where companies have brought manufacturing back to the US and saved money (or seen negligible cost differences), but those are a minority, not a majority. If the compnay was able to charge more for the products then they could make them here.  Wages go up. Unemployment (while already low) gets "better" as people shift away from lower paying jobs to less lower paying jobs. Oh, and this hoses everything in the economy, not just those products because those new manufacturing jobs compete for all labor, pushing that up across the board.  But, congratulations, you have "ended our unemployment problem." Or you could just raise wages across the board. Starting with the minimum wage. The second thing is education. A better educated workforce will earn more money.  There will be more innovation. There will be a greater chance of an entrepreneur coming out of the woodwork and creating a new business. But education costs money. So dig deep in your pocket. Job training. Vocational schools. Taxes.   So, to sum it up, first, you must learn how to phrase the problem. We do not have an "unemployment crisis" because unemployment is at historic lows. Instead we have a wage crisis where the wages are not keeping pace with the cost of living. The answer to how to fix that is not popular, nor is it cheap.  How do you fix it? With costs to you and me and unpopular decisions by politicians.  Which is why you should not expect to fix the problem any time soon.

Even if we all were saints, viewed work as worship, and sought diligently to be productive some amount of unemployment due to the search, matching, and creative-destructive processes would exist and be required. That does not mean that I would advocate no assistance for the newly unemployed or unemployable. But all solutions also require a level of morals, ethics, and diligence sadly lacking today in even the most developed economies in order to be efficient and beneficial. And all solutions are expensive and involve taxes if some form in order to provide such social insurance and we must be willing to pay such taxes.

It may sound a bit obvious but creating jobs is the best way. The problem comes in how you create the jobs and what the jobs are. If you look at demographics and birth rates then you can see how many jobs are going to be needed each year quite easily. This can be planned out some 16 years in advance. The question is then how do you create those jobs. There are two obvious ways for a state to do this. Either the state employs those people or encourages business growth so that private companies can employ the people. Issues start arising if you try to do one or the other of these quickly. The first one is limited by the funds of the state. Eventually the state exists to create jobs for people to gather money to the state (from those very peoples pay) to create more jobs for people in the state’s employ whose job it is to create jobs for the state. A focus on such a system has glaring weaknesses. If everyone is employed by the state then you have to tax everyone enough to pay those people. While this can be passed out through various different sectors you end up with a relatively stagnant system. There is a lack of competition and opportunities for advancement can easily be stifled. If you go the other way then you have to rely on those private businesses paying people enough to be able to live. One of the biggest issues in the UK at the moment is rising costs while the wages aren’t rising or in many cases are dropping in real terms. To counteract this the state needs to step in with regulation. Businesses with a lot of power then try to avoid these regulations and can get away with unethical practices. What you need is a way of creating jobs at the rate of population increase. If you have a set retirement age then you recoup jobs at that point but there are plenty of jobs people do after they retire, this kind of semi-retirement can be quite common in industries with a strong consultancy arm. The skills and experience are valuable while the hours can be picked up as and when people want them. Let’s get a little deeper. The job market is just that a market. Labour has a price. When there are less jobs than people the strength is on the side of the employer. The employer can then set low wage rates. This then means that people may need two or more jobs. That further reduces the job opportunities. People need work to pay for things therefore they have to take the badly paid jobs, at least until they can find better paid ones. To tackle this issue you need to tackle saturation in the employee market place. Immigration is often touted as a contributory factor. Low and unskilled labour can be done by anyone from anywhere with a basic command of the host country’s language. If you reduce immigration or cap it and regulate who can enter then you can put more power into the hands of the employees and therefore drive wages up. Companies not paying well will quickly find themselves struggling for staff. They then need to up their pay or go out of business. How does the pay angle fit into this? Decent pay means that the employee can spend more. It also means the government gets more tax revenue. If you can’t tax the people as they don’t have enough money then you have to tax corporations, those corporations can then up and leave the country for tax reasons. See amazon and the tax revenue issues with that across Europe and in particular with relation to the UK. So in essence to create jobs you need to raise the demand for services and goods from companies. The more orders a company has (or work in general) the more staff they need. To get that revenue you need people spending that money. To give people disposable cash you need decent wages. What can be seen is there is the carrot and the stick. You need to make working attractive and not working unattractive. The carrot being decent pay to buy a house and lots of nice things. The stick being stuck with no money in a bad area. The issues here are that if people have nothing then they have nothing to lose which increases crime. If you don’t give decent wages then there is no incentive to work. The best way therefore to keep enough jobs around is to have a country that is business friendly but with a strong safety net for those who find themselves out of work. That safety net should allow time for the individual to retrain if needed and for them to be able to live until they can find another job. Even so far as to be able to offer them employment. This can be done with infrastructure projects. A nice simple one here is roads. Roads always need repairing and updating. The same with rail systems. If you use that money from welfare support to pay contractors to fix those things you create jobs for all of those people on welfare who need the jobs. There is another way though. Universal basic income. Scrap all state benefits and state pensions. Replace this with a flat rate of money for everyone. In one swoop you have simplified the whole welfare system making the process streamlined and at the same time giving all of those low earners a bump in income. Sound good? it does but what effect will it have and where will the money come from? If you scrap benefits you have that whole budget to use. So that is sorted. The system is simplified meaning the running costs save you an absolute ton of money. Cap the payment so those earning say £150,000 or more lose the money. This is slightly higher than the rate you lose the tax free personal allowance currently. You also scrap the tax free personal allowance as that is your new universal income. That ups revenue significantly. Businesses don’t have to worry about losing any money and lots of people have way more money to spend. You destroy poverty rapidly making society on the whole wealthier. There are some other implications though. If everyone has more money then money becomes worth less in real terms leading to inflation. This could make the whole concept moot. The way to tackle this would be a series of cost caps and fixing prices for a few years to iron out the system. This gets around the opportunists who would suddenly charge more. There is a further effect socially. There is a potential issue that people will go ‘sod this I’m not working if I get free money’. That means less tax revenue leading to system collapse. This is a tricky subject though. What it may well do is put the power back in the hands of the employee. They get treated badly they walk without worrying.
